title: Games Firm Jam City Buys Ludia
text:
Jam City's deal with Ludia parent Fremantle also adds a slate of coming mobile-game titles, including from Disney and DC Comics, the company said. Fremantle, a subsidiary of broadcaster RTL Group, acquired a 29% stake in Ludia in 2009 and later took full ownership. Since 2013, Ludia has doubled its revenue, RTL Group said.

Chris DeWolfe, co-founder and chief executive of Jam City, said the company was interested in Ludia because of its work with Hollywood intellectual property and its high-quality games, which use technology such as augmented reality and mixed reality.

"It became imperative for us to move more quickly on this deal," Mr. DeWolfe said, adding that Jam City had been in discussions with Freemantle and Ludia for a long time.

Los Angeles-based Jam City also said it raised $350 million in equity and debt financing from Netmarble Games Corp., the largest mobile-gaming company in South Korea, Kabam Inc.; and affiliates of funds managed by Fortress Investment Group.

Jam City, which owns 10 mobile-game studiosand was founded by two Myspace co-founders and a former Twentieth Century Fox executive, said the Series D funding round is its largest and will be used to do more acquisitions and expand its existing portfolio. The company has raised a total of $650 million.

Over the past several years, Jam City has focused on finding studios with engaging games that haven't had the capital or time to build technology platforms to best support them, said Mr. DeWolfe, who previously co-founded and served as CEO of Myspace.

The company has touted its Jam City Live platform, which it has spent millions of dollars to develop, as an advantage that can help create lasting game franchises by aiding player retention and monetization.
